review.title: Defense semantics of argumentation: encoding reasons for accepting arguments
review.abstract: In this paper we show how the defense relation among abstract arguments can be used to encode the reasons for accepting arguments. After introducing a novel notion of defenses and defense graphs, we propose a defense semantics together with a new notion of defense equivalence of argument graphs, and compare defense equivalence with standard equivalence and strong equivalence, respectively. Then, based on defense semantics, we define two kinds of reasons for accepting arguments, i.e., direct reasons and root reasons, and a notion of root equivalence of argument graphs. Finally, we show how the notion of root equivalence can be used in argumentation summarization.

sections.heading: 6 Conclusions
sections.text: In this paper, we have proposed a defense semantics of reasoning based on a novel conception of defense graphs, and used it to encode reasons for the acceptance of arguments. By introducing two new types of equivalence relations between arguments, i.e. defense equivalence and root equivalence, we have shown that defense equivalence can be used to grasp the equivalence of argument graphs from the perspective of reasons for the acceptance of arguments. Furthermore, we have defined a concept of summarizing argument graphs by exploiting root equivalence. Under complete semantics, defense equivalence is between strong and standard equivalence. It is interesting to further examine their position in the so-called argumentation zoo, where other equivalence concepts between the two extreme versions are also compared [13], and to investigate how defense equivalence, root equivalence, and strong equivalence relate to each other.
